content: Select a large litter box. Small boxes are available for tiny kittens, but kittens grow up so fast that you'll have to replace the litter box soon after introducing it. When you replace a litter box you have to retrain the kitten, so it's better to start with a box you plan to use for a long time. Kittens have no trouble getting into large litter boxes, as long as one side is low enough that they can step inside. If you find a great box but aren't sure whether the kitten will be able to climb inside, use a piece of plywood or another flat material with good traction to make a little ramp. Affix it to the side of the litter box using duct tape, and remove it when the kitten has grown big enough to get inside without it. Consider an enclosed litter box. Some litter boxes have an enclosure (or top) around them. The advantage of the enclosed litter box is that it can contain the litter for an enthusiastic kicker/digger and it may cut down smells if you have the box in a small living area. Some cats also feel protected by the enclosure. [2] Be sure that the enclosed litter box is large; cats need enough room to comfortably turn around inside the box. Most cats have a behavioral need to sniff their feces and then bury them, and the box needs to allow plenty of room for that. [3] Some cats do not like enclosed boxes when initially introduced to them. You can ease the transition by removing the swinging door until your cat becomes acclimated to the box. Buy kitty litter. There are many types of litter to chose from, and most types litter are fine for most juvenile or adult cats (8 months or older.) Select a litter that is as dust-free as possible, since dust can irritate cats’ lungs. [4] You might want to keep the following factors in mind as you make your choice: Do not use clumping cat litter for kittens. If they eat it (which they do) it sticks together in their gut and can cause a serious impaction. Use unscented litter if possible. Kittens and cats may not like perfumed litter; if the scent is overpowering, they may use bathroom somewhere else. [5] Additionally, some scents could irritate a cat’s nose and eyes or cause problems for cats who are prone to respiratory problems. Consider a scoopable litter. Scoopable litter has become a popular choice, since it makes removing the kitten's waste quite easy. Be aware that there is some concern that a cat could become sick from ingesting scoopable litter, but that there is little or no evidence of this happening. [6] [7] Select a litter that is widely available. Some cats become accustomed to a specific litter and may not recognize the tray as a toilet unless it contains their usual litter. Purchase a scooper and drop cloth. The last things you need to get ready for litter training your kitten are a scooper for removing waste from the litter box and a drop cloth to place under the box to prevent stray litter from soiling your house. Place the box in a peaceful location. Don't put it in a high-traffic area of your home, like the kitchen or entry hall. The ideal litter box location is easily accessible, offers plenty of privacy, and is free from sudden noises that could frighten a kitten. [8] Though a laundry room is a popular choice for a location because it has less traffic than other areas of most houses, the sudden noises that a washer or dryer can make while switching cycles could frighten a kitten and cause her to fear using the box. [9] The litter box should be in an area that a kitten spends a lot of time. The kitten should be able to see the litter box most of the time so that she can use it if she needs to. Kittens and cats prefer a little privacy. If they don't have it, they may start relieving themselves behind the sofa or in another out-of-the-way corner. [10] If you start litter training a kitten and it becomes necessary to move the box, do it gradually, a few feet at a time every few days. Moving the box to a different room from one day to the next could confuse the kitten and lead to accidents around the house. It may also help to place the kitten’s food bowl where the litter box used to be, as most cats are reticent to use the toilet where they eat. Place the kitten in the filled litter box. As soon as you bring the kitten home, place her in the box so she can get used to the smell and feel of the kitty litter. Let her spend a few minutes there, even if she doesn't go to the bathroom the first time. Continue to place the kitten in the box after she eats meals, wakes up, or any other time when you predict she may need to relieve herself. In addition, if she squats anywhere other than the litter box place her in it immediately. Some kittens will understand the purpose of the litter box immediately and require no additional litter training. Others will need to be placed in the litter box as many as ten times a day before they figure it out. You should avoid attempting to "show" the kitten the digging motion that cats use to bury their waste as it may frighten them, so avoid the temptation to take her paws and help her dig into the litter until she catches on. [11] Use praise, not punishment. As the kitten grows used to the litter box and starts using it as her toilet, praise her each time she goes by petting her and making comforting sounds. Do not discipline her while she is in the box, or she might start associating being in the box with punishment. [12] Kittens do not respond well to having their noses rubbed in a mess they have made outside the litter box. If she has an accident, let her sniff the mess, then gently lift her and put her in the box, so she knows where to go next time. Never spank or yell at a kitten to punish her. It will only serve to make her afraid of you. Provide enough litter boxes. If possible, you should have one litter box for each cat in your house, plus an additional litter box. For example, one kitten should ideally have 2 litter box options. If you have three cats, you should provide four litter boxes. Consider a confinement period. When you first introduce a kitten to your home, you may want to confine her to a small area for the first few weeks. This can help her acclimate slowly to her new environment, will give her easy access to her litter box, and can help minimize or confine accident areas. [13] You may want to confine the kitten to an area without carpet to make accidents easier to clean if they do occur. Keep the litter box and the kitten’s food and bedding at opposite ends of the confinement area. [14] Clean the litter every day. Kittens do not like to relieve themselves in dirty areas. If you don't change the litter, the kitten may find a cleaner place, like the carpet, to do her business. To clean the litter box, scoop the waste out of the box, place it in a small baggie, close the bag, and throw it away. You can leave a small bit of feces in the litter box (changing it frequently) during the first few weeks. This helps the kitten recognize what the box is for. Clean the entire litter box frequently. About once a week, you will need to completely dump the contents of the litter pan and give it a thorough cleaning. Once the pan is emptied out, wash it with a non-hazardous cleaning solution (or warm soapy water), then rinse the pan, dry it, and refill it with clean litter. [15] It can be tempting to leave scoopable litter for longer than one week due to the ease of removing the cat’s waste. However, even scoopable litter needs to be completely emptied and replaced frequently. Clean accident areas thoroughly. If your kitten or cat uses the bathroom outside of the litter box, be sure that you completely clean the area, removing all traces of urine or feces. This should help reduce repeat accidents in the same area. [16] Consider removing large potted plants from your home. If you find that your kitten is using the dirt in your potted plants for a toilet, you may need to remove them or cover the dirt with foil during litter training. Kittens instinctively bury their waste, so they may be attracted to dirt or sandy areas. Make sure the litter box is the only place in the house where they want to relieve themselves. Feed the kitten at regular times. This will help you be able to predict when she will need to use the litter box. Kittens generally feel the urge to have a bowel movement about 20 minutes after eating. When you think she has the urge to go, take her to the box and let her climb inside.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Litter-Train-a-Kitten">How to Litter Train a Kitten</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Purchasing_Supplies_sub" id="">Purchasing Supplies</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Introducing_the_Kitten_to_the_Litter_Box_sub" id="">Introducing the Kitten to the Litter Box</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Keeping_Your_Kitten_Comfortable_sub" id="">Keeping Your Kitten Comfortable</a>
<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Expert Q&A</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>. Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">17 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Kittens naturally like to relieve themselves in dirt or sand. If you introduce them to a litter box, they'll gladly go there instead of on your carpet. If you start as soon as you bring your kitten home, he or she will be using the box regularly in no time. It is important to find the right box for your kitten and encourage her to use it, but you won’t need to "litter train" a cat in the same way you would house-train a dog. You shouldn’t need to teach your cat what to do with a litter box; instinct will generally take over. You do need to provide an acceptable, accessible litter box.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup></p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Purchasing_Supplies_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Purchasing_Supplies">Purchasing Supplies</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_3e816c1633" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3e816c1633')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Select a large litter box.</b> Small boxes are available for tiny kittens, but kittens grow up so fast that you'll have to replace the litter box soon after introducing it. When you replace a litter box you have to retrain the kitten, so it's better to start with a box you plan to use for a long time.

<ul>
<li>Kittens have no trouble getting into large litter boxes, as long as one side is low enough that they can step inside. If you find a great box but aren't sure whether the kitten will be able to climb inside, use a piece of plywood or another flat material with good traction to make a little ramp. Affix it to the side of the litter box using duct tape, and remove it when the kitten has grown big enough to get inside without it.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-2-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-2-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_952969e6aa" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_952969e6aa')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-2-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider an enclosed litter box.</b> Some litter boxes have an enclosure (or top) around them. The advantage of the enclosed litter box is that it can contain the litter for an enthusiastic kicker/digger and it may cut down smells if you have the box in a small living area. Some cats also feel protected by the enclosure.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Be sure that the enclosed litter box is large; cats need enough room to comfortably turn around inside the box. Most cats have a behavioral need to sniff their feces and then bury them, and the box needs to allow plenty of room for that.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Some cats do not like enclosed boxes when initially introduced to them. You can ease the transition by removing the swinging door until your cat becomes acclimated to the box.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_8d9efea948" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8d9efea948')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Buy kitty litter.</b> There are many types of litter to chose from, and most types litter are fine for most juvenile or adult cats (8 months or older.) Select a litter that is as dust-free as possible, since dust can irritate cats’ lungs.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup> You might want to keep the following factors in mind as you make your choice:

<ul>
<li>Do not use clumping cat litter for kittens. If they eat it (which they do) it sticks together in their gut and can cause a serious impaction.</li>
<li>Use unscented litter if possible. Kittens and cats may not like perfumed litter; if the scent is overpowering, they may use bathroom somewhere else.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Additionally, some scents could irritate a cat’s nose and eyes or cause problems for cats who are prone to respiratory problems.</li>
<li>Consider a scoopable litter. Scoopable litter has become a popular choice, since it makes removing the kitten's waste quite easy. Be aware that there is some concern that a cat could become sick from ingesting scoopable litter, but that there is little or no evidence of this happening.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Select a litter that is widely available. Some cats become accustomed to a specific litter and may not recognize the tray as a toilet unless it contains their usual litter.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-4-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-4-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-4-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_a9d27e805e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a9d27e805e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-4-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Purchase a scooper and drop cloth.</b> The last things you need to get ready for litter training your kitten are a scooper for removing waste from the litter box and a drop cloth to place under the box to prevent stray litter from soiling your house.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Introducing_the_Kitten_to_the_Litter_Box_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Introducing_the_Kitten_to_the_Litter_Box">Introducing the Kitten to the Litter Box</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-5-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-5-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_d1c80e09c4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d1c80e09c4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Place the box in a peaceful location.</b> Don't put it in a high-traffic area of your home, like the kitchen or entry hall. The ideal litter box location is easily accessible, offers plenty of privacy, and is free from sudden noises that could frighten a kitten.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Though a laundry room is a popular choice for a location because it has less traffic than other areas of most houses, the sudden noises that a washer or dryer can make while switching cycles could frighten a kitten and cause her to fear using the box.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>The litter box should be in an area that a kitten spends a lot of time. The kitten should be able to see the litter box most of the time so that she can use it if she needs to.</li>
<li>Kittens and cats prefer a little privacy. If they don't have it, they may start relieving themselves behind the sofa or in another out-of-the-way corner.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If you start litter training a kitten and it becomes necessary to move the box, do it gradually, a few feet at a time every few days. Moving the box to a different room from one day to the next could confuse the kitten and lead to accidents around the house. It may also help to place the kitten’s food bowl where the litter box used to be, as most cats are reticent to use the toilet where they eat.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-6-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-6-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-6-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_375299ae18" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_375299ae18')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-6-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Place the kitten in the filled litter box.</b> As soon as you bring the kitten home, place her in the box so she can get used to the smell and feel of the kitty litter. Let her spend a few minutes there, even if she doesn't go to the bathroom the first time. Continue to place the kitten in the box after she eats meals, wakes up, or any other time when you predict she may need to relieve herself. In addition, if she squats anywhere other than the litter box place her in it immediately.

<ul>
<li>Some kittens will understand the purpose of the litter box immediately and require no additional litter training. Others will need to be placed in the litter box as many as ten times a day before they figure it out.</li>
<li>You should avoid attempting to "show" the kitten the digging motion that cats use to bury their waste as it may frighten them, so avoid the temptation to take her paws and help her dig into the litter until she catches on.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-7-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-7-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_21f257ae4e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_21f257ae4e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-7-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use praise, not punishment.</b> As the kitten grows used to the litter box and starts using it as her toilet, praise her each time she goes by petting her and making comforting sounds. Do not discipline her while she is in the box, or she might start associating being in the box with punishment.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Kittens do not respond well to having their noses rubbed in a mess they have made outside the litter box. If she has an accident, let her sniff the mess, then gently lift her and put her in the box, so she knows where to go next time.</li>
<li>Never spank or yell at a kitten to punish her. It will only serve to make her afraid of you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_aa48708226" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_aa48708226')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Provide enough litter boxes.</b> If possible, you should have one litter box for each cat in your house, plus an additional litter box.

<ul>
<li>For example, one kitten should ideally have 2 litter box options. If you have three cats, you should provide four litter boxes.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_3ddd210293" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3ddd210293')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider a confinement period.</b> When you first introduce a kitten to your home, you may want to confine her to a small area for the first few weeks. This can help her acclimate slowly to her new environment, will give her easy access to her litter box, and can help minimize or confine accident areas.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>You may want to confine the kitten to an area without carpet to make accidents easier to clean if they do occur.</li>
<li>Keep the litter box and the kitten’s food and bedding at opposite ends of the confinement area.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Keeping_Your_Kitten_Comfortable_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Keeping_Your_Kitten_Comfortable">Keeping Your Kitten Comfortable</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f0872188c5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f0872188c5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Clean the litter every day.</b> Kittens do not like to relieve themselves in dirty areas. If you don't change the litter, the kitten may find a cleaner place, like the carpet, to do her business.

<ul>
<li>To clean the litter box, scoop the waste out of the box, place it in a small baggie, close the bag, and throw it away.</li>
<li>You can leave a small bit of feces in the litter box (changing it frequently) during the first few weeks. This helps the kitten recognize what the box is for.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-11.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_7f812e23e5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7f812e23e5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-11.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Clean the entire litter box frequently.</b> About once a week, you will need to completely dump the contents of the litter pan and give it a thorough cleaning. Once the pan is emptied out, wash it with a non-hazardous cleaning solution (or warm soapy water), then rinse the pan, dry it, and refill it with clean litter.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>It can be tempting to leave scoopable litter for longer than one week due to the ease of removing the cat’s waste. However, even scoopable litter needs to be completely emptied and replaced frequently.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-12.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_678e2ec2d3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_678e2ec2d3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-12.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Clean accident areas thoroughly.</b> If your kitten or cat uses the bathroom outside of the litter box, be sure that you completely clean the area, removing all traces of urine or feces. This should help reduce repeat accidents in the same area.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-13.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_673c5489a6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_673c5489a6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-13.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider removing large potted plants from your home.</b> If you find that your kitten is using the dirt in your potted plants for a toilet, you may need to remove them or cover the dirt with foil during litter training. Kittens instinctively bury their waste, so they may be attracted to dirt or sandy areas. Make sure the litter box is the only place in the house where they want to relieve themselves.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=134577" href="#/Image:Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_055a9940b2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_055a9940b2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Litter Train a Kitten Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg/aid134577-v4-728px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Feed the kitten at regular times.</b> This will help you be able to predict when she will need to use the litter box. Kittens generally feel the urge to have a bowel movement about 20 minutes after eating. When you think she has the urge to go, take her to the box and let her climb inside.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="134577" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="162162" data-caid="163035" data-cqid="162179" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="558437" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="46">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is it safe to train a one-week old kitten to use the litter tray?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Very young kittens such as this are not able to empty their own bladder and bowel, but hold on and only toilet when stimulated to do so by their mother licking. Also, the kitten is not yet able to walk and is still blind so they won't be able to find their way to the tray and climb in. By all means have a litter tray set up for the kitten to use, so they can discover it as they become mobile, but a one-week old kitten still needs their toileting needs seen to by the mother. 
</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>7</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>46</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="452160" data-caid="453033" data-cqid="452177" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="8">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Why is my kitten eating the cat litter?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Kittens tend to investigate things with their mouths and it's not unusual for kittens to eat litter. For this reason, never use clumping cat litter if you have a kitten. The swallowed litter could clump in their stomach and cause a serious blockage. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>8</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="162163" data-caid="163036" data-cqid="162180" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="600201" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="13" data-votes_up="56">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My kitten doesn't use her litter box and when I try to put her in it she gets scared and runs away. What should I do?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">This sounds like you kitten has accidentally learned to associate the tray with distress and has developed an aversion to using it. Set up another litter box in a different location and use a different substrate so there is nothing that she can link mentally to the other tray. When she poops or pees, place it in this new tray so as to give her the idea its a toilet. Play things low key and never place her in the box and hold her there or she may develop a bad association. </div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="452158" data-caid="453031" data-cqid="452175" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Why is my kitten meowing at me?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If the kitten is not hungry and has recently been to the litter box, it may be that she's asking for attention. Try brushing her and playing with her for a few minutes, and she may settle down for a contented sleep.</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="452159" data-caid="453032" data-cqid="452176" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="7">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">At what age do kittens start using the litter box?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Most kittens follow their mother into the litter box once they are old enough to leave the nest (3 weeks or so). Before this age, the mother usually licks and cleans the kittens so that they don't soil the nest. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="452157" data-caid="453030" data-cqid="452174" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="129" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do you train a kitten to go in a litter box?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a><br/>
	Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons
</div>
Dr. Elliott is a veterinarian with over thirty years of experience. She graduated from the University of Glasgow in 1987, and worked as a veterinary surgeon for 7 years. Afterward, Dr. Elliott worked as a veterinarian at an animal clinic for over a decade.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" style="background-image: url(/images/thumb/1/1c/Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg/-crop-200-200-150px-Pippa_Elliott1.jpeg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs#pippaelliott%2Cmrcvs" target="_blank">Pippa Elliott, MRCVS</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Veterinarian, Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Most kittens are good at training themselves! Simply provide a litter box with low edges and pop the kitten in after she has eaten. It also helps if she has another cat to copy. </div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="38292" data-caid="39165" data-cqid="38309" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="14868" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="21" data-votes_up="89">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I adopted a 3 month old kitten fairly recently. She is already litter trained but on the first night she leaked a little where she was sleeping. I'm wondering if that was just because she didn't know where the litter was?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Kittens of that age will leak here and there while learning to use the litter. Simply pick her up each time you catch her urinating and place her into the litter tray. Try to add some of the mopped up urine to the tray to help her to identify the tray with the odor. She'll grasp it soon enough. In the meantime, quickly clean up any small messes to deter reuse of that area.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>89</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="111148" data-caid="112021" data-cqid="111165" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="811937" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="10" data-votes_up="38">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">If my kitten was a stray and was not litter-box-trained, how do I get him to use the litter box?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">The same way you would for any cat.  Even strays have the instinct to bury their waste, so just follow these same steps. </div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="41841" data-caid="42714" data-cqid="41858" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="289112" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="25" data-votes_up="73">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What age should I introduce my kitten to the litter box?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can introduce your kitten to the litter box at any age. If it's mother was there, she would probably put the kitten in there herself as soon as the kitten was able.</div>

<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="41850" data-caid="42723" data-cqid="41867" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="356986" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="23" data-votes_up="63">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My kitten.  How do I get my kitten out of her habit of urinating beside the litter box when I am not at home?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">After your kitten is done eating, wait for 20 minutes. Then, carefully pick her up and put her in the litter box. She will smell the scent and get used to it, and this may help her stop. Also try to put something she wouldn't want to step on on the spot where she shouldn't be going, such as tin foil, or a spiky carpet protector, flipped up so the spikes are up.</div>

<center>
</center>
<p>How to litter train your cat.</p>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>As your kitten grows, you will need to put more litter in the pan. By the time your kitten is six months old, you should start placing two to three inches of litter in the pan.</li>
<li>Praise your cat as this enforces the repetition of the desired good behavior.</li>
<li>If your kitten seems hesitant to use her litter box, ensure that she is able to access the box easily or try changing to a different litter, particularly if the litter is scented.</li>
<li>Change litter gradually. If you find that you need to change a cat’s litter type, try transitioning slowly from one litter to the next by mixing new litter with the old, slowly increasing the amount of “new” litter over a period of about two weeks.</li>
<li>If you have a relatively large house or apartment, you may want to consider providing multiple litter boxes. This ensures that if your kitten has to go urgently, that he or she will use a litter box rather than another area of the house. As your kitten uses the boxes more reliably, you can begin to remove litter boxes gradually.</li>
<li>It's best if you have a house with tile or wood flooring because that way the pee can be mopped up.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Make sure you have your new kitten checked by your veterinarian to ensure it is healthy to begin with. Some illnesses cause kittens and cats to behave differently when it comes to the litter pan.</li>
<li>Feed your kitten a canned (wet) food specifically for kittens. They get dehydrated more easily than adult cats, which can lead to litter box and health problems.</li>
<li>A common reason a kitten relives itself outside of the litter is if the owner chastised the kitten for using the wrong spot. The kitten may then feel insecure about going to the toilet (especially in an open space) for fear of being punished, and becomes secretive. With this in mind, never chastise your kitten for going in the wrong place because it only makes matters worse.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To litter train your kitten, start by placing the litter box in a peaceful location where your kitten won't be disturbed. Next, put the kitten in the box after it eats, wakes up, or any time you think it may have to relieve itself. When the kitten uses the litter box correctly, reward it by petting it and making comforting sounds. Then, continue to put the kitten in the box at regular intervals until it learns to go there on its own. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For tips from our Veterinary reviewer on keeping your litter box tidy and clean-smelling, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Litter Train a Kitten",
    "name": "Litter Train a Kitten",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",

    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cb\/Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg\/aid134577-v4-1200px-Litter-Train-a-Kitten-Step-14.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",

            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Pippa Elliott, MRCVS"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Purchasing Supplies",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Select a large litter box. Small boxes are available for tiny kittens, but kittens grow up so fast that you'll have to replace the litter box soon after introducing it. When you replace a litter box you have to retrain the kitten, so it's better to start with a box you plan to use for a long time.\n\nKittens have no trouble getting into large litter boxes, as long as one side is low enough that they can step inside. If you find a great box but aren't sure whether the kitten will be able to climb inside, use a piece of plywood or another flat material with good traction to make a little ramp. Affix it to the side of the litter box using duct tape, and remove it when the kitten has grown big enough to get inside without it."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider an enclosed litter box. Some litter boxes have an enclosure (or top) around them. The advantage of the enclosed litter box is that it can contain the litter for an enthusiastic kicker\/digger and it may cut down smells if you have the box in a small living area. Some cats also feel protected by the enclosure.[2]\nBe sure that the enclosed litter box is large; cats need enough room to comfortably turn around inside the box. Most cats have a behavioral need to sniff their feces and then bury them, and the box needs to allow plenty of room for that.[3]\nSome cats do not like enclosed boxes when initially introduced to them. You can ease the transition by removing the swinging door until your cat becomes acclimated to the box."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Buy kitty litter. There are many types of litter to chose from, and most types litter are fine for most juvenile or adult cats (8 months or older.) Select a litter that is as dust-free as possible, since dust can irritate cats\u2019 lungs.[4] You might want to keep the following factors in mind as you make your choice:\n\nDo not use clumping cat litter for kittens. If they eat it (which they do) it sticks together in their gut and can cause a serious impaction.\nUse unscented litter if possible. Kittens and cats may not like perfumed litter; if the scent is overpowering, they may use bathroom somewhere else.[5] Additionally, some scents could irritate a cat\u2019s nose and eyes or cause problems for cats who are prone to respiratory problems.\nConsider a scoopable litter. Scoopable litter has become a popular choice, since it makes removing the kitten's waste quite easy. Be aware that there is some concern that a cat could become sick from ingesting scoopable litter, but that there is little or no evidence of this happening.[6][7]\nSelect a litter that is widely available. Some cats become accustomed to a specific litter and may not recognize the tray as a toilet unless it contains their usual litter."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Purchase a scooper and drop cloth. The last things you need to get ready for litter training your kitten are a scooper for removing waste from the litter box and a drop cloth to place under the box to prevent stray litter from soiling your house."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Introducing the Kitten to the Litter Box",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Place the box in a peaceful location. Don't put it in a high-traffic area of your home, like the kitchen or entry hall. The ideal litter box location is easily accessible, offers plenty of privacy, and is free from sudden noises that could frighten a kitten.[8]\nThough a laundry room is a popular choice for a location because it has less traffic than other areas of most houses, the sudden noises that a washer or dryer can make while switching cycles could frighten a kitten and cause her to fear using the box.[9]\nThe litter box should be in an area that a kitten spends a lot of time. The kitten should be able to see the litter box most of the time so that she can use it if she needs to.\nKittens and cats prefer a little privacy. If they don't have it, they may start relieving themselves behind the sofa or in another out-of-the-way corner.[10]\nIf you start litter training a kitten and it becomes necessary to move the box, do it gradually, a few feet at a time every few days. Moving the box to a different room from one day to the next could confuse the kitten and lead to accidents around the house. It may also help to place the kitten\u2019s food bowl where the litter box used to be, as most cats are reticent to use the toilet where they eat."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Place the kitten in the filled litter box. As soon as you bring the kitten home, place her in the box so she can get used to the smell and feel of the kitty litter. Let her spend a few minutes there, even if she doesn't go to the bathroom the first time. Continue to place the kitten in the box after she eats meals, wakes up, or any other time when you predict she may need to relieve herself. In addition, if she squats anywhere other than the litter box place her in it immediately.\n\nSome kittens will understand the purpose of the litter box immediately and require no additional litter training. Others will need to be placed in the litter box as many as ten times a day before they figure it out.\nYou should avoid attempting to \"show\" the kitten the digging motion that cats use to bury their waste as it may frighten them, so avoid the temptation to take her paws and help her dig into the litter until she catches on.[11]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use praise, not punishment. As the kitten grows used to the litter box and starts using it as her toilet, praise her each time she goes by petting her and making comforting sounds. Do not discipline her while she is in the box, or she might start associating being in the box with punishment.[12]\nKittens do not respond well to having their noses rubbed in a mess they have made outside the litter box. If she has an accident, let her sniff the mess, then gently lift her and put her in the box, so she knows where to go next time.\nNever spank or yell at a kitten to punish her. It will only serve to make her afraid of you."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Provide enough litter boxes. If possible, you should have one litter box for each cat in your house, plus an additional litter box.\n\nFor example, one kitten should ideally have 2 litter box options. If you have three cats, you should provide four litter boxes."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider a confinement period. When you first introduce a kitten to your home, you may want to confine her to a small area for the first few weeks. This can help her acclimate slowly to her new environment, will give her easy access to her litter box, and can help minimize or confine accident areas.[13]\nYou may want to confine the kitten to an area without carpet to make accidents easier to clean if they do occur.\nKeep the litter box and the kitten\u2019s food and bedding at opposite ends of the confinement area.[14]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Keeping Your Kitten Comfortable",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Clean the litter every day. Kittens do not like to relieve themselves in dirty areas. If you don't change the litter, the kitten may find a cleaner place, like the carpet, to do her business.\n\nTo clean the litter box, scoop the waste out of the box, place it in a small baggie, close the bag, and throw it away.\nYou can leave a small bit of feces in the litter box (changing it frequently) during the first few weeks. This helps the kitten recognize what the box is for."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Clean the entire litter box frequently. About once a week, you will need to completely dump the contents of the litter pan and give it a thorough cleaning. Once the pan is emptied out, wash it with a non-hazardous cleaning solution (or warm soapy water), then rinse the pan, dry it, and refill it with clean litter.[15]\nIt can be tempting to leave scoopable litter for longer than one week due to the ease of removing the cat\u2019s waste. However, even scoopable litter needs to be completely emptied and replaced frequently."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Clean accident areas thoroughly. If your kitten or cat uses the bathroom outside of the litter box, be sure that you completely clean the area, removing all traces of urine or feces. This should help reduce repeat accidents in the same area.[16]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider removing large potted plants from your home. If you find that your kitten is using the dirt in your potted plants for a toilet, you may need to remove them or cover the dirt with foil during litter training. Kittens instinctively bury their waste, so they may be attracted to dirt or sandy areas. Make sure the litter box is the only place in the house where they want to relieve themselves."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Feed the kitten at regular times. This will help you be able to predict when she will need to use the litter box. Kittens generally feel the urge to have a bowel movement about 20 minutes after eating. When you think she has the urge to go, take her to the box and let her climb inside."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],

If you introduce them to a litter box, they'll gladly go there instead of on your carpet. If you start as soon as you bring your kitten home, he or she will be using the box regularly in no time.
